filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of an electronic edition of 20 of Blake’s water color illustrations to the Bible. These designs illustrate the Old Testament and are arranged according to the passages illustrated. They are presented in our Preview mode, one that provides all the features of the Archive except Image Search and Inote (which provides detailed descriptions of Blake’s images).
The Bible had an enormous influence on Blake’s work as both artist and poet. Among his many and complex responses to that text are water color drawings. The present group of 20 is selected from a sequence of about 80 biblical water colors of similar size Blake painted for Thomas Butts between c. 1800 and c 1806. These designs emphasize interactions between the human and the divine. In works such as
Ezekiel’s Wheels and David Delivered Out of Many Waters , the interaction is revelatory or redemptive. In other designs, including Pestilence: The Death of the First-Born , the relationship between God and humankind devolves into punishment and destruction.
This group of 20 water colors is the first installment in our publication of a large selection of Blake’s water color drawings illustrating the Bible. In coming months we will publish a group of New Testament illustrations also from the series executed for Butts. Later we will add early works, such as Abraham and Isaac , datable to c. 1780, and continue through Blake’s final biblical water colors, including Moses Placed in the Ark of the Bulrushes of c. 1824.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

objdescid.origination: Anonymous delineator. The inscriptions on the mount (the backing mat) below the water color, available under Related Works in the Archive, are not by Blake. They could not have been written before 1846, the earliest known date for the production of the paper on which the inscriptions are written. The identity of the calligrapher who wrote the inscriptions is not known. There may have been an inscription on the mount above the water color, as in other examples with similar inscriptions on the mounts of Blake's biblical water colors. If once present, such an inscription was trimmed off the mount at an unknown time.

provenance.note: Acquired, and probably commissioned, from Blake by Thomas Butts in 1806; by inheritance in 1845 to Thomas Butts, Jr.; sold from his collection, Foster and Son auction, London, 29 June 1853, lot 133 (£1.1s. to the book dealer Henry G. Bohn); Joseph A. Paton; sold from his collection, Chapman's auction, Edinburgh, 12 Nov. 1874, lot 1189 (no price or purchaser recorded); in the possession of John Crosby by 1876; Mrs. A. R. Crosby, probably by inheritance; sold from her collection, Sotheby's, 6 April 1925, lot 152 (£600 to the dealer Frank T. Sabin, possibly acting for Grenville L. Winthrop); bequeathed by Winthrop in 1943 to the Fogg Art Museum, Harvard University.

desc.objtitle:
By the Waters of Babylon,
Object 1 (Butlin 466)

objnote.p: Blake signed the work, lower right, with his monogram and dated it.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This design illustrates Psalms 137:1-3. In the center of the design sits a group of enslaved Israelites, perhaps a family, beneath a tree. The rightmost figure is an old man with long hair and a beard. He wears a gown and faces forward, with his knees drawn up and his arms crossed. He looks to the left at his captors. He has a shackle on his left ankle. His facial expression suggests despair. The second-to-right figure of this group is that of a gowned male(?) with short, curly hair. He faces left and draws his knees up. He holds his head in his hands and hides his face. His posture suggests despair. He also has a shackle on his left ankle; a chain extends to the shackle on the ankle of the old man to the right. The third-to-right figure of this group is a female with long hair. She faces forward and to the left and may have her mouth slightly open. In her right hand, she holds an infant. The the next figure to the left in this group is an infant who faces forward, right, and slightly up. Its gender is indeterminable. Its eyes are closed and it may be sleeping. The third-to-left figure of this group is a gowned male child with short, curly hair. He stands facing forward, but leaning against the female who may be his mother. He turns his head up and to the right to look at her. His right hand rests on the shoulder of the figure to the left, perhaps his sister. The second-to-left figure is that of a young girl with long, slightly curly hair and a gown. She stands, facing forward and slightly right. She leans against the male figure to her right and rests her head on his shoulder; her right arm is at her side and with her right hand she holds the neck of the figure to the left. The leftmost figure of this group is that of a young male with short, curly hair. He sits or crouches with his left leg bent under him and his right leg drawn up and perhaps on tiptoe. He faces forward and to the right and looks upward. He wears a gown. On the right side of the design stand two partly clothed male figures with short, curly hair; they are probably enslaved Israelites. The figure to the left wears a loincloth and faces forward and to the left, leaning against a long oar that he holds. His right ankle has a shackle on it and he bends his right leg so that it is on tiptoe. His arms are bent upward and he may be looking at the seated group to the left. The figure to the right also bends his right leg and faces forward and to the left, looking slightly down. He leans against an oar that he holds in his right hand. On the left side of the design stands a group of five figures, presumably the victorious Babylonians. The leftmost figure is that of a male with long, curly hair and a beard. He faces right and slightly forward and probably wears a gown. He may look at the seated group of Israelites. Only the long hair of the next figure to the right is pictured. The middle figure of this group is an old man with a long beard and curly hair. He is presumably a king because he wears a spiky crown on his head. He faces right and slightly forward and may look at the seated group of Israelites. He wears a gown and holds his right arm at his side, in which hand he holds a scepter topped with what appears to be a fleur-de-lis. The second-to-right figure of this group is that of an armored male with short, curly hair. He faces forward and right. The armor around his waist resembles scales and he wears a crown of laurel leaves in his hair. He may be a soldier. He may look at the group of seated Israelites. His left arm is at his side and with that hand he holds the right hand of the figure to the right. The rightmost figure of this group is that of a female in an elaborate gown and with a plumed hat draped with pearls or beads. She also wears long pearl or bead earrings and a pearl or bead bracelet. She has long, curly hair that is slightly pulled up into a bun. She faces forward and to the right and looks down at the seated group of Israelites. With her right hand she holds the left hand of the figure to the left. Her left arm is raised at 135 degrees and with her left hand she points at the musical instruments in the tree. The armored Babylonian male holds a spear and at least three spears are visible to the left. The central group of Israelites sits beneath a tree (identified in psalm 137 as a willow) with long branches. On the branches of the tree are hung a lyre, a curved horn, a straight horn, and a harp. In the foreground of the scene are waves, indicating the rivers of Babylon. A river winds through the background. The ground beneath the figures' feet is grassy. To the right of the Babylonian woman are three small figures standing in the background on the bank of the river, facing away and to the right. Their legs are spread as they stand on the river bank, perhaps walking or running. Six boats are visible on the river in the background, most with sails but at least one appears to be a barge. The city of Babylon is visible in the background, built along the riverbanks. Most buildings have columns and several have domes, though at least one spire is visible. In the background of the scene, a hill rises from the river. The riverbanks are marked by indeterminate, leafy vegetation.

The central group of Israelites sits beneath a tree (identified in psalm 137 as a willow) with long leafless branches.
On the branches of the tree are hung a lyre, a curved horn, a straight horn, and a harp.

The ground beneath the figures' feet is grassy.

To the right of the Babylonian woman in the background are three small figures in the background. They are of indeterminate gender, facing away and to the right. Their legs are spread as they stand on the river bank, perhaps walking or running.
Six boats are visible on the river in the background, most with sails but at least one appears to be a barge.

The city of Babylon is visible in the background, built along the riverbanks. Most buildings have columns and several have domes, though at least one spire is visible. Steps lead from one building to the river bank.
The riverbanks are marked by indeterminate, leafy vegetation.
In the background of the scene, a hill rises from the river.

lg.l: By the waters of Babylon we sat down & wept when we remembered thee,
O Jerusalem; as for our harps, we hanged them up in the trees which are therein.
